title: 106_hr263
content: The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" imposes an excise tax on individuals acquiring structured settlement payments in factoring transactions, as outlined in Chapter 55 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Structured Settlement Protection Act" imposes a 50 percent tax on acquiring structured settlement payment rights in factoring transactions, with exceptions for court-approved hardships. The term 'structured settlement' refers to an arrangement for periodic payments of damages or compensation that are excludable from the recipient's gross income, as defined in section 104(a)(1) and 104(a)(2). The payments must meet the criteria outlined in section 130(c)(2) and are made by a party to the agreement or someone who has assumed liability. The term 'structured settlement payment rights' refers to the rights to receive payments under a structured settlement. A 'structured settlement factoring transaction' is a transfer of these payment rights for consideration through sale, assignment, pledge, or other forms of encumbrance. The 'factoring discount' is the excess amount of undiscounted structured settlement payments. The term 'relevant court or administrative authority' in structured settlement transactions refers to the jurisdiction overseeing the underlying action or claim resolved by the structured settlement. The structured settlement must be brought to a court or administrative authority with jurisdiction over the claim or the residence of the recipient. Any structured settlement factoring transaction should not affect the tax provisions if the requirements of sections 72, 130, and 461(h) were met at the time of the settlement. The Secretary can issue regulations for clarification in such events. The Secretary can issue regulations to clarify the treatment of amounts received in a structured settlement factoring transaction. Information reporting requirements are amended in the tax code. "Reporting requirements for structured settlement factoring transactions are outlined in SEC. 6050T." "In structured settlement factoring transactions, the person making the payments must provide a written statement to the acquirer of the payment rights as per section 6041 or as prescribed by the Secretary. These reporting obligations replace other provisions in this part." The provisions of this section establish reporting obligations for structured settlement factoring transactions, replacing other provisions in this part. The term 'acquirer of the structured settlement payment rights' includes any person described in section 7701(a)(1). The amendments in Chapter 55 require reporting on structured settlement factoring transactions, effective for transactions occurring after the enactment of the Act.
